title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The Dee, where it is spanned by this bridge, is hurried between two rocks, which leave a space only of twenty feet for its ample waters. Twenty-six miles from Aberdeen and eight from Banchory is the village of Kincardine  O'Neil — [Inn : The Gordon Arms] — a neat village, not so well wooded as Banchory, but frequented in summer by invalids,  from its pure and bracing air. On the right hand, about half a mile to the north, are Kincardine Lodge (Francis Gordon,  Esq.), and a mile beyond, Desswood House (Alexander Davidson, Esq.)

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
